questions.question: The institution responsible for regulating the non-military aviation in Portugal is:
options: Secretaria de Estado das Infraestruturas, Transportes e Comunicações (The State Agency for Infrastructure, Transport and Communications).
Instituto Nacional de Aviação Civil, IP(National Institute for Civil Aviation).
Instituto da Mobilidade e Transportes, IP(Institute for Mobility and Transport).
Federação Portuguesa de Voo Livre (Portuguese Free Flight Federation).

questions.question: In Portugal, the sport organism responsible for regulating the free flight is:
options: Secretaria de Estado das Infraestruturas, Transportes e Comunicações.(State Agency for the Infrastructure, Transports and Communications)
Instituto Português de Desporto e Juventude – IP. (Portuguese Institute of Sport and Youth)
Instituto Nacional de Aviação Civil – IP. (National Institute for Civil Aviation)
Federação Portuguesa de Voo Livre (Portuguese Free Flight Federation)

questions.question: The Regulation of Instruction and Titles (RIT) of the FPVL is a technical document that:
options: It can only be altered by the schools with valid working permit.
Establishes 5 levels of free flight pilot.
Regulates the instruction, titles and training of free flight pilots and instructors.
Regulates all the FPVL activity concerning competition and training.

questions.question: The revalidation of the pilot license obliges to the demonstration that the pilot as done:
options: In the 12 months before the revalidation request , at least 200 flights in every class or type of aircraft registered in the license.
In the 5 months before the revalidation request , at least 5 flights in every class or type of aircraft registered in the license.
In the 12 months before the revalidation request , at least 5 flights in every class or type of aircraft registered in the license.
None of the above.

questions.question: The requirements to obtain the Free Flight License are:
options: 16 years and finishing the compulsory education.
16 years regardless of finishing the compulsory education.
18 years and finishing the compulsory education.
18 years regardless of finishing the compulsory education.

questions.question: The flight rules establish that, in open air, when two pilots are in collision route:
options: Each pilot should turn right.
Each pilot should turn left.
The priority goes to the less experienced pilot.
None of the above.

questions.question: The flight rules establish that when flying close to a ridge if two pilots are in a collision course:
options: Each pilot should turn right.
Each pilot should turn left.
The priority goes to the less experienced pilot.
None of the above.

questions.question: It is allowed to practice Free Flight
options: In non-controlled airspace with a NOTAM issued.
Inside the clouds only when we can see the GPS.
In controlled airspace only during competition and with communication with Air Traffic Control.
In military areas, flying below 300 meters.

questions.question: Restricted areas are zones in which:
options: It is not allowed to fly.
It is allowed to fly but there are potential dangers to the air navigation.
It is allowed to fly with authorization from the air traffic control.
None of the above.

questions.question: The current legislation:
options: Obliges the revision of the wings every 6 months.
Establishes areas where no other aircraft can fly.
Obliges the paragliding pilots to fly VFR.
Establishes that, with all the instruments we carry (GPS and vario), the competition pilots can fly IFR.

questions.question: To improve the efficiency of the emergency parachute we should open it, air it and fold it:
options: Every month.
Every 18 months.
Every 6 months.
Every 12 months.

questions.question: When falling with the parachute the arrival at the ground is violent. The pilot should:
options: Run as fast as you can.
Use the Roulé Boulé technique.
Spread the legs and bend the knees and body.
Put the legs together and look at the sky.

questions.question: If the parachute gets damaged in the landing the pilot should:
options: Fix it with what he has on hand.
Put it in the garbage.
Send it to a qualified technician so that it can be repaired.
No repair is needed because the probability of ever using it in this life is very small.

questions.question: When doing the inspection of the emergency parachute one should:
options: Leave it in the shade to air out at least one day.
Iron each wrinkle, preferably with a cool iron.
Hang it in the sun for a few hours to eliminate all the moist.
Spread some resin in the lines to reduce the friction.

questions.question: When doing the inspection of the emergency parachute the pilot should have in mind:
options: The temperature of the day so that the lines don’t suffer additional stretching.
The relative humidity of the day, in order to keep the parachute with some moist.
The place where it will be folded in order to keep it clean from animals and dirt.
Do it only in the morning.

questions.question: At a take-off at 3.800 meters:
options: The necessary speed to take off is the same as taking off at sea level.
Hypoxia symptoms are a factor to be aware.
Due to the cold the helmet should be substituted by a wool cap.
The only possible way to take off is with reverse launch due to the wind gradient.

questions.question: The potential risk of the paragliding activity is greatly raised with the use of:
options: Energetic drinks.
Orange juice.
Natural juices.
Alcohol and drugs.

questions.question: When a pilot has a severe inflammation of the hearing system and/or of the vestibular system he should:
options: Fly low.
Fly without restriction.
Fly slowly.
Fly on another day.

questions.question: Capability to fly:
options: Regardless the health condition of the pilot if he can fly he should not stay in the ground. Practice leads to perfection.
When symptoms of illness or fatigue are present the decision to fly on another day is the better option.
Even if the night rest was not enough the pilot should fly because the weather may not be good the next time.
When a pilot is not in good physical condition he should make distance flights so he can practice and get more fit doing this.

questions.question: If a pilot as done scuba diving he should wait before flying:
options: If he has done one single dive, 5 days.
If he has done one single dive, 8 days.
If he has done several dives or several days diving, 30 days.
None of the above.

questions.question: A low pressure originated by thermal activity:
options: Is formed by the heating of the lower layers of the atmosphere.
Will get stronger when the precipitation cools the air below.
The circulation of cold air in the lower levels can help its beginning.
None of the above.

questions.question: An adiabatic process is a thermodynamic process in which:
options: There are no swaps of pressure with the surroundings.
There are swaps of pressure with the surroundings.
There are no swaps of heat with the surroundings.
There are swaps of heat with the surroundings.

questions.question: In a situation with strong wind:
options: It´s a good factor that helps the organization of good thermals because the wind is a good trigger.
It´s a good factor that helps the organization of strong thermals.
It´s a good factor that helps the continuous release of bubbles not allowing enough time for consistent thermals to form.
None of the above.

questions.question: In case of a strong and consistent thermal the wind:
options: Breaks it and turns it in to a turbulent situation.
Goes around it like a normal obstacle creating zones of windward and leeward.
It blasts down the gradient and the thermal.
None of the above.

questions.question: The amount of water that the air can store depends on the temperature and the purity of that air.
options: The lower the temperature and the higher the purity, higher quantity of water it can hold.
The higher the temperature and the higher the purity, lower quantity of water it can hold.
The higher the temperature and the higher the purity, higher quantity of water it can hold.
There is no relation between the amount of water that the air can hold and its temperature and purity.

questions.question: Formation of clouds:
options: After the passage of a cold front we might have showers, many cumulus and periods of blue sky.
A cloud formed by the convection has its origin in a mass of air that goes up and never reaches the dew point.
The formation of cirrostratus is a good indicator of thermal activity.
The cumulus humilis are always formed in the presence of a low pressure or when a hot front is passing.

questions.question: Clouds classification concerning its height:
options: Cirrus are middle clouds (between 3.000m and 6.000m).
Cumulonimbus are low clouds (below 3.000m).
Altocumulus are high clouds (more than 6.000m).
Nimbostratus are middle clouds (between 3.000m and 6.000m).

questions.question: Stratus are:
options: High clouds that block the solar heating.
Low clouds without structure.
Clouds that are indicators of good flying conditions.
Clouds associated with strong thermals.

questions.question: In an atmosphere with the characteristic described in the chart below, a mass of air with a trigger point of 26ºC and with a dew point temperature of 8ºC at 600m:
options: It will go up until 3.060m where it forms a cloud.
It will go up until 2.600m where it reaches the ceiling.
It will go up until 2.050m where it will find a strong inversion.
It will go up until 3.850m where it reaches the ceiling.

questions.question: With the data from the previous chart. The air mass:
options: Will form a cloud around 2.050m.
Will form a cloud around 3.060m.
Will form a cloud around 3.850m.
It won’t form a cloud because it won’t reach the dew point temperature..

questions.question: We look for thermals in areas:
options: Soft and green.
With strong thermal contrast.
With soft thermal contrast.
Without thermal contrast.

questions.question: In order to better utilize the thermal lift:
options: If it´s strong and narrow the pilot should turn in a tighter circle.
If it´s strong and narrow the pilot should turn in a wider circle.
If it´s weak and wide the pilot should turn in a tighter circle.
To turn in a wider or narrow circle has no relation with the dimension or strength of the thermal.

questions.question: In the presence of wind, in order to better utilize the thermal lift, the pilot should:
options: Make a lot of short turns in order to be as centered as possible.
Make a zig-zag in order to be as centered as possible.
Follow the drift of the thermal in order to be as centered as possible.
None of the above.

questions.question: To make the most of the flight, the pilot should go from one thermal to the next when:
options: There are other pilots going up in the same thermal.
There are other pilots in the same thermal but they can’t go up.
The thermal is getting weak and it is possible to reach a better one.
The thermal is strong and the lift rate is high.

questions.question: When inside of a thermal, the pilot should:
options: Stay as still as possible.
Seek constantly the strongest core.
Leave the thermal several times to find the edges of the lift.
Fly in a straight line.

questions.question: As the day passes the thermals get:
options: Weaker around 15 hours.
Stronger at the evening.
Weaker at the evening.
Maintain their strength.

questions.question: In the MacCready theory the calculations have their base in:
options: The wing coefficient of lift and drag.
The level of wing torsion.
The wing polar curve.
The wing aspect ratio.

questions.question: The MacCready ring gives indication about the speed that the pilot should have based in:
options: Strongest lift ahead, fly faster.
Strongest lift ahead, fly slower.
Strongest lift ahead, maintain the medium speed of the wing.
None of the above.

questions.question: In an accident:
options: The most important is to call a person that the victim knows.
The most important is to cry really high for help.
The cardiac arrest is a situation of primary help.
To keep the victim immobilized is not relevant.

questions.question: On a primary survey to the victim the most important is:
options: To know the name and phone number of the victims contact.
Don’t act if you’re not a licensed rescuer.
To move away the danger from the victim, avoiding more accidents.
Protect the victims property.

questions.question: In order to achieve the maximum performance from the flight the optimization of the speed is fundamental. The pilot should:
options: In the presence of lift fly faster.
With tail wind fly faster.
With head wind fly faster.
None of the above.

questions.question: Regarding the glide and wing loading of a profile:
options: The best glide is not altered by the wing loading.
The best glide is obtained with a lower wing loading.
The best glide is obtained with a higher wing loading.
None of the above.

questions.question: A strong decrease in the angle of attack might cause:
options: A stall.
A frontal collapse.
An asymmetric collapse.
A parachutage.

questions.question: In order to better optimize the thermal lift if the pilot makes the turn to slow the wing can go into:
options: Asymmetric stall.
Sustained stall.
Parachutage.
Dynamic stall.

questions.question: Aerodynamic:
options: The speed decreases when the angle of attack decreases.
The speed increases when the angle of attack increases.
The speed increases when the angle of attack decreases.
None of the above.

questions.question: When the wing loading increases a wing will go in a stall at a horizontal velocity:
options: Lower.
Equal
Higher.
The increase of the wing loading has no relation with the stall speed.

questions.question: In order to keep himself inside of the thermal a pilot acts on both brakes symmetrically. If he decreases the velocity too much he will make:
options: Asymmetric stall.
Complete stall.
Frontal collapse.
Asymmetric collapse.

questions.question: After an asymmetric collapse a pilot should:
options: Make a full stall to recover from the collapse.
Use the speed system to control the pitch.
Stop the wing from turning.
Raise both hands to allow the wing to recover from the collapse faster.

questions.question: The pitch movement happens on the axis:
options: Vertical and it should be stopped with a symmetrical action on the brakes.
Lateral and it should be stopped with a symmetrical action on the brakes.
Longitudinal and it should be stopped with a symmetrical action on the brakes.
The free flight aircrafts don´t make pitch movements.

questions.question: The pitch should be controlled because it may cause:
options: Asymmetric stall.
Total stall.
Frontal collapse.
Asymmetric collapse.

questions.question: Regarding the equipment:
options: The trailing edge is the front of the wing when it is in flight.
Stabilizers are the anchor points of the wing to the hangers.
Cell is the portion of the wing comprised between two main internal profiles.
The extruder is the underside of the wing when it is in flight.

questions.question: With regard to the type-approval of equipment, tests shall be carried out on:
options: Structural and flight resistance.
Structural strength, longevity and durability of the material.
Flight to calculate the best performance.
None of the above.

questions.question: Measuring instruments:
options: An anemometer measures the accuracy of the wind.
An altimeter works based on the variation of the atmospheric pressure.
A variometer works based on the wind speed variation.
A tuned wind sleeve always points north.

questions.question: Why does the air move?
options: The atmosphere constantly tries to match the pressure and temperature differences caused by the differential heating of the regions.
The atmosphere constantly tries to equalize the differences in pressure and humidity caused by the distinct humidity of the regions.
The atmosphere constantly tries to equalize the differences in humidity and temperature caused by the distinct humidity of the regions.
The atmosphere does not have any interference in this process.

questions.question: In a system of high pressures the wind circulates:
options: Counter-clockwise if in the northern hemisphere.
Counter-clockwise if in the southern hemisphere.
Counter-clockwise in both hemispheres.
Clockwise in both hemispheres.

questions.question: The leeward could be:
options: The side where the dynamic flight is made.
A dangerous place full of rotors.
The part of the obstacle exposed to the wind.
None of the above.

questions.question: The earth breeze is mainly due to:
options: Overheating of the land relative to the sea.
Differential heating of land and sea.
Warming of land and sea.
It has no relation to the warming of land and sea.

questions.question: Sea breezes, usually:
options: It blows during the afternoon on the east coast of mainland Portugal.
It blows during the night and morning on the west coast of mainland Portugal.
It blows during the afternoon on the west coast of mainland Portugal.
It is dry and turbulent.

questions.question: The vertical movements of the air:
options: They originate from the uniform heating of the earth's surface.
They are always very smooth and stable.
They may prevent safe flight practice.
None of the above.

questions.question: It's high clouds:
options: Cumulonimbus Cumulus, Nimboestrates and Stratus.
Cirrus, cirrostratus and cirrocumulus;
Altostratus, Altocumulus and Stratocumulus.
None of the above.

questions.question: Cirrus clouds are:
options: White convection and fibrous appearance.
High, white, translucent, formed by ice crystals.
Greyish thick and without definite shape.
Greyish looking, making the sky appear to be covered with large sheep.

questions.question: For frontal surfaces:
options: A frontal system is always associated with strong north wind.
When passing a cold front we always have sun and blue sky.
A front is a line separating two air masses of different characteristics, mainly in temperature and humidity.
A front may be fresh, hot or a little warm.

questions.question: Frontal systems are associated with:
options: Low pressure systems.
Depressive valleys.
High pressure systems.
Barometric marshes.

questions.question: Before flying, the pilot must:
options: Plan your flight with a high precision chart.
Wash the chair and clean all equipment.
Plan your flight and check the NOTAM to see if there is any aerial activity planned for the location and the trajectory.
Call the FPVL to request a NOTAM.

questions.question: Ears (wing surface decrease) are used in paragliding for:
options: Reduce the rate of fall.
Increase the rate of fall.
Maintain the rate of fall.
It is an instability manoeuver that should only be used by very experienced pilots.

questions.question: To fly around without any external influence, a paraglider tends to:
options: Up.
Maintain altitude.
Descend.
Close.

questions.question: With regard to the study of velocities of a given profile, a velocity polar is established in the relation between:
options: The maximum speed and the rate of ascent.
The horizontal speed and the rate of ascent.
The vertical velocity and the horizontal velocity.
The vertical velocity and the rate of fall.

questions.question: Turbulence track are air disturbances left:
options: Only by large aircraft.
Only by motor aircraft.
Only by non-powered aircraft.
By any aircraft in flight.

questions.question: In the event of an accident in a very windy place
options: Control of the wing should be a concern.
The thermal protection of the victim is irrelevant.
First of all, you should remove the victim of the chair/ harness and protect it from the wind.
None of the above.

questions.question: In case of bleeding caused by a stick in the leg:
options: Apply heart massage.
Not acting, awaiting the arrival of adequate means of assistance;
Apply indirect manual compression at the femoral artery.
Apply direct manual compression at the site of bleeding.

questions.question: After a violent landing in the middle of cliffs, the victim complains of headaches, appears confused, drowsy and vomits. We suspect:
options: Internal bleeding.
Fracture.
Cranial trauma.
Hypothermia.

questions.question: The principle of support has as reference, with regard to its more usual explanation, the flow of air in the upper surface relative to the lower surface, being:
options: The lowest velocity in the lower surface is higher in the upper surface.
Same velocity in the lower surface and the upper surface.
The lowest velocity in the upper surface is higher in the lower surface.
In this explanation, there is no relation between the velocity of the air in the upper surface and that of the lower surface.

questions.question: The RFA is the sum of the forces:
options: Weight and resistance.
Sustainability and Resistance.
Support and weight.
None of the above.

questions.question: When in motion, a wing is subject to resistances:
options: Pressure and friction.
Pressure. Only when above 28Km / h.
Friction. Only when above 28Km / h.
None of the above.

questions.question: A wing may stall if the pilot:
options: Decrease its speed below the maximum speed of flight.
Decreases its speed below the minimum speed of flight.
It increases its speed above the maximum speed of flight.
It increases its speed above the minimum speed of flight.

questions.question: On a wing with speed, hands on top or neutral bar, of 40 km/h that moves at 45 km/h, we can consider that:
options: It moves with wind front in the order of 15 km/h.
It moves with wind from the back in the order of 15 km / h.
It moves in a descending one with a speed of rise in the order of the 1,5m/s.
It moves in an ascending one with a speed of rise in the order of the 1,5m/s.

questions.question: Civil aviation organizations:
options: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has its seat in Switzerland.
The Chicago Convention, signed on 7 December 1944, was set up in the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA).
The FPVL is a National Authority for Light Aircraft Aviation (Paragliding and Delta Wing) and Auxiliary Engine (Paramotor).
None of the above.

questions.question: In Portugal, a sports regulator for Free Flying and Paramotor is:
options: The Ministry of Transport.
A State Secretariat for Youth and Sport.
The Portuguese Institute of Youth and Sports.
Portuguese Free Flight Federation (FPVL).

questions.question: The Instruction and Titling Regulations of the FPVL is a technical document that:
options: Only FPVL schools with a valid operating license can change it.
Established the entire training structure for pilots and instructors of Free Flight and Paramotor.
Regulates all associative activity of FPVL.
Only General Assembly of the FPVL can change it.

questions.question: The Learning License:
options: It is valid for 1 year and can be consecutively revalidated for 5 years.
Allows the student to fly, even without the presence of the instructor responsible.
It is possible to have it from the age of 14.
It is possible to have it from the age of 16.

questions.question: Requirements for obtaining a Pilot License:
options: 14 years old and completed compulsory minimum education.
16 years old.
18 years old and completed the minimum compulsory schooling.
21 years old.

questions.question: The renewal of a pilot license has not been valid for 3 years, it obliges:
options: 12 months prior to the renewal request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
In the 3 months prior to the request for renewal, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
Have passed a flight test administered by a flight examiner in each of the classes or types of aircraft, less than 3 months ago.
Have passed a written exam for less than 6 months.

questions.question: Flight rules state that:
options: When two paraglider pilots are on a collision course, one increase and one decrease.
Non-powered aircraft have priority over the rest.
Paraglider has priority over a balloon.
Paramotor has priority over a Paraglider.

questions.question: It is allowed the practice of Free Flying
options: Exclusively in airspace controlled in direct and constant communication with the air traffic management.
Exclusively in uncontrolled airspace in direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
Within clouds since you can still see the GPS.
None of the above.

questions.question: Prohibited areas may be associated with the defense of a state, and are areas where:
options: To enable identification of the aircraft it is mandatory to fly below 300 meters.
It is only allowed to fly when expressly authorized.
It is allowed to fly below 300 meters, but there are potential dangers to air navigation, so it is up to the pilot / commander to use them.
It is not allowed to fly under any circumstances.

questions.question: Current legislation:
options: Prevent the practice of Free Flying in aerial area type G.
establish flight practice areas where any other aircraft may fly.
Requires the pilot to have a personal accident insurance and a civil liability insurance.
None of the above.

questions.question: The minimum flight velocity of a wing is one in which the wing:
options: It has the capacity to fly faster.
Is close to the velocity of loss.
Can run better.
Can no longer hold.

questions.question: The anti-forgetting system in the flight chair
options: It is part of the connection of the chair to the elevators;
It is part of the connection of the acceleration system of the wing that is in the chair.
Compose ABS crusader systems.
It is part of the leg straps when they are independent;

questions.question: The acquisition of a wing by a pilot candidate must take into account
options: High performance with regard to glide and velocity.
Only the best price you will get at your subsequent sale.
The advice of the instructor with whom the training was given.
Only the greater durability of the material from which it is made.

questions.question: Hyperventilation phenomena at altitude:
options: They originate the greatest amount of oxygen available in these places.
They are characterized by a calm and deep breathing.
May cause dizziness, vertigo, chest pain and / or fainting.
None of the above.

questions.question: On a take off at about 1.000 meters altitude:
options: Headaches and disorientation may be a symptom of hypoxia.
Nausea and vomiting can not be symptoms of hypoxia.
Uncoordinated movements may be hypoxia symptoms.
None of the above.

questions.question: The valsalva maneuver should be used.
options: With the decrease of the altitude/ increase of the atmospheric pressure.
As altitude increases/ decreases atmospheric pressure.
Only underwater diving activities.
Never. There is no effect of altitude/ air pressure variation on the perineal ears and sinuses.

questions.question: With signs of anxiety and fear,
options: It is not worrisome for the pilot, they are natural things for the person who flies.
The pilot may have to make adjustments to the flight plan or even cancel it.
No importance should be given as long as there is no danger of panic.
Immediately the pilot should be taken to a hospital emergency.

questions.question: For greater safety of the pilot in the practice of Free Flying, it is recommended:
options: Ignore their psychological state, for fear of flying is a natural thing for humans.
Be influenced to take off by other people.
Never fly alone.
Ignore warnings from more experienced pilots.

questions.question: The wind has origin ...
options: ... in the attempt of the atmosphere to equalize the pressure and temperature differences caused by the differential heating of the regions.
... in the constant movement of the earth (Rotation and translation).
... in the force of Coriolis.
... in inertia phenomena.

questions.question: The wind
options: Viscosity and turbulence do not affect the wind.
The effect of Coriolis only influences the local winds (Brisas).
The temperature does not influence the wind.
The direction and intensity of the wind can be conditioned by the relief.

questions.question: Large distances from isobars indicate:
options: Light wind or no wind at all.
Moderate wind.
Strong wind.
The proximity or spacing of the isobars has no relation to the wind velocity.

questions.question: Valley and mountain breezes:
options: Hill breezes originate from the same heating of the plain relative to the hill.
The intensity and duration of the hill breeze is directly proportional to its size.
To make the hill breeze stronger, the air is drawn from the atmosphere to the mountains.
When the mountains are part of a mountain range, it is impossible to create a system of breezes with air drawn from the nearby plains.

questions.question: The sea breeze is mainly due to:
options: Overheating of the land relative to the sea.
Overheating of the sea to the earth.
Equal warming of land and sea.
There is no relation between the warming of the land and the sea with the sea breeze.

questions.question: Stratus are clouds:
options: Low, without structure, thin and uniform.
Averages, grayish-white in which the sky seems covered with sheep.
High, translucent white and of a more or less compact fibrous aspect.
High, thick gray and without form.

questions.question: In their classification of altitude, we consider high clouds:
options: Cirrus, cirrostratus and cirrocumulus;
Cumulonimbus Cumulonimbus, Nimbostratus and Stratus.
Altostratus, Altocumulus.
None of the above.

questions.question: Frontal system occlusion:
options: It is a unique and very unlikely meteorological phenomenon to happen.
It occurs when the cold front reaches the hot front.
It occurs when the hot front reaches the cold front.
It is given when the cold front slows down and then stops.

questions.question: The preparation and planning of the flight.
options: Provides for the need to consult active NOTAMs.
Due to the unpredictability of the weather, Free Flight is an activity of improvisation, any preparation or planning is dispensable.
Due to the type of flight, it should only take into account the logistics organization of the group that will fly.
It is a funny theoretical theme but without any practical applicability for Free Flight.

questions.question: Take-off
options: "Alpine" should be the preferred technique when there is a weak wind.
"Reverse" should be the preferred technique in low wind situations.
The run must be done by jumping to correct the pressure faults in the wing.
None of the above.

questions.question: Spiral is a maneuver ...
options: ... very radical. It should not be used.
... to be used only by competition riders.
... delicate, so that their learning should be done progressively.
... used to climb with more velocity.

questions.question: A polar is established in the relation between:
options: The maximum velocity and the rate of climb;
The vertical and the horizontal velocity.
The horizontal velocity and the rate of ascent.
The vertical velocity and the rate of fall.

questions.question: On approach to landing.
options: Like any aircraft, paragliders are required to comply with the aeronautical approach.
The technique of approximation in L is the one that allows to make a better recognition of the terrain.
In strong wind conditions, it is impossible to miss the landing site with the U approach technique.
The technique in O is the best way to recognize the terrain from all points of view.

questions.question: In the case of a large unintentional asymmetrical collapse the pilot must:
options: Support the natural tendency of rotation of the wing to the side of the collapse.
Counteract the natural tendency of rotation of the wing to the side of the collapse.
Raise and lower the hands several times and quickly.
Not intervene. Let the wing act naturally which it recovers by itself.

questions.question: In an accident in a place with wind
options: Control of the wing is not very important.
The thermal protection of the injured is irrelevant.
First of all, you must remove the injured person from the chair/ harness.
None of the above.

questions.question: A pilot who, upon landing, has a foot trauma whose position appears to be different from normal, a fracture must be suspected. Therefore, we should proceed as follows:
options: Remove the footwear and place the foot in the normal position for the pilot to have less pain.
Do not remove the footwear and try to immobilize the foot in the position in which it is.
Remove the footwear and try to immobilize the foot in the position in which it is.
None of the above.

questions.question: In case of venous hemorrhage:
options: Always apply, simultaneously with any other action in the veins, direct manual compression in the two carotid arteries in order to decrease circulating blood pressure.
Apply, immediately and always, indirect manual compression. For reasons of contamination.
Always apply direct manual compression if there are no strange things in the wound.
It acts only to reassure the victim and await the arrival of adequate means of assistance.

questions.question: After a very violent landing in the middle of cliffs, the victim complains of abdominal pain, appears pale, with cold sweats and thirsty. We suspect:
options: Internal bleeding in the abdomen and we should not give him water. Just wet his lips.
Cranial trauma and we should not give him water. Just wet his lips.
Acute appendicitis and we should not give him water. Just wet his lips.
Fracture of the transverse abdominal bone and we should not give it water. Just wet his lips.

questions.question: The principle of support has as reference, with regard to its more usual explanation, the flow of air in the intruder relative to the extruder, being:
options: The highest velocity in the extruder is lower in the intruder
The lowest velocity in the extruder is higher in the intruder.
The same velocity in the extruder and the intruder.
None of the above.

questions.question: Aerodynamic performance:
options: It is a relation between the sustentation that the wing produces and its resistance of form.
It is a relation between the support that the wing produces and the parasitic resistance caused by the rest.
It is a relation between lift and resistance, known as L / D (Lift / Drag).
It is too theoretical a concept typical of airplanes and does not apply to our aircraft.

questions.question: The wing produces lift and all the rest resistance.
options: When several types of resistance combine, they create even greater resistance, that of interference.
The shape resistance is produced only by the pilot position.
The induced resistance is due to the viscosity of the air.
The friction resistance is due to the deflection of the air at the trailing edge back and forth.

questions.question: The boundary layer:
options: In paragliding the boundary layer has a laminar flow.
The air adheres to the object due to its viscosity.
Paragliding is only turbulent near the point of stagnation.
There is no boundary layer in paragliders.

questions.question: ​​A wing whose velocity hands above is 44km/h and that at a given moment moves at 22km/h, we can consider that:
options: It moves with 22 km/h front wind.
It moves with 22 km/h back wind.
It moves in an 2,2m/s ascending (climbing).
It moves in a 2,2m/s descending (falling).

questions.question: When making a turn too slow the wing can easily enter:
options: Sustained stall.
Asymmetric stall.
Dynamic stall.
Parachuting.

questions.question: The definition of wingloading is expressed as follows:
options: The relationship between the weight of the wing and its surface.
the relationship between the total weight of the flight equipment and the wing surface.
The relationship between the total weight in flight (pilot and equipment) and the wing surface.
None of the above.

questions.question: In aerodynamic terms:
options: Decreasing the angle of attack the speed decreases.
Decreasing the angle of attack increases speed.
Increasing angle of attack increases speed.
None of the above.

questions.question: The pitch must be well controlled as it may cause:
options: Asymmetric stall.
Total stall.
Front collapse.
Asymmetric collapse.

questions.question: The General Assembly of the Portuguese Free Flight Federation is an organ ...
options: ... FPVL management executive.
... technician where schools decide about instruction.
... administrative that manages the way licenses are issued.
... of maximum decision and in which all pilots, instructors and judges are represented.

questions.question: The Instruction and Titles Department (DIT) of the Portuguese Free Flight Federation is an organ...
options: ... executive.
... technical.
... administrative.
... associative

questions.question: The current sports legislation and regulations:
options: It requires personal accident insurance for all members of sports federations.
Obliges to have personal accident insurance only for pilots competing.
Obliges to have a civil liability only to pilots who compete.
None of the above.

questions.question: In competition, the first instance to appeal in case of complaints about problems that occurred during the day's race is:
options: The Organizer.
The Director of the Competition.
The Competition Judge.
The President of FPVL.

questions.question: Flight rules provide that:
options: A Paramotor has priority over a Paraglider.
Aircraft with engines have priority over the others.
A balloon has priority over a paraglider.
None of the above.

questions.question: The renewal of pilot licenses that has not been valid for 5 or more calendar years requires the demonstration of this having made:
options: In the 12 months prior to the renewal request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
In the 3 months prior to the renewal request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.

Demonstration of having passed a flight test administered by a flight examiner in each of the relevant classes or types of aircraft less than 3 months ago and having passed a written theory test less than 6 months ago.
None of the above.

questions.question: The practice of Free Flight is allowed
options: Exclusively in controlled air spaces in direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
Exclusively in uncontrolled air spaces in direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
Exclusively in uncontrolled air spaces regardless of being in direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
None of the above.

questions.question: In “uncontrolled airspace” (Class G):
options: Competition flights are allowed.
The practice of Free Flight and Paramotor is not allowed;
Flight within clouds is permitted.
None of the above.

questions.question: Prohibited areas can be associated with the defense of a state, so they are areas where:
options: For reasons of identification, it is only allowed to fly below 5,000 feet (about 1,500m).
It is allowed to fly only when expressly authorized.
It is allowed to fly but there are potential dangers for air navigation, so it is up to the pilot / commander to use it.
It is not allowed to fly under any circumstances.

questions.question: The most common emergencies that require the use of an emergency parachute are:
options: Front closures at high altitude.
Strong closures at high altitude.
Tangle of tissue in the wires (ties).
None of the above.

questions.question: When parachuting, landing on the ground is violent, so you should:
options: Run as much as you can.
Spread your legs and flex your knees and torso.
Use the technique of Roulé Boulé.
Put your legs together and look at the sky.

questions.question: For the parachute to work as efficiently as possible, it is necessary that:
options: Have the connections and the extraction system in good working condition.
The connecting carabiners are quick-opening.
The fabric is sufficiently porous for air to penetrate and open better.
The cords have been well separated at the time of folding.

questions.question: The wing and the wires should not be stepped on, especially on rocky terrain. If this happens, you should:
options: Inspect it, make a report for the brand and have the wires in question replaced.
Inspect it immediately and decide according to the damage verified.
Get the wing ready immediately and send it to the equipment inspection entity.
Get the wing ready immediately and check it in detail at home.

questions.question: If the parachute is damaged during a landing, the pilot must:
options: Do not repair it as the probability of using it again is very low.
Kill it immediately.
Repair it with the material to which you have access.
Use qualified personnel to repair or replace it.

questions.question: Taking off at 4,200 meters above sea level:
options: The take-off speed is equal to the speed required at sea level.
Symptoms of hypoxia should be a factor to consider.
The only possible way to take off is to stop, due to the wind speed.
None of the above.

questions.question: Pressure effects on the ears and sinuses:
options: With the decrease in pressure (rising), the valsalva maneuver should be used.
With increasing pressure (going down), the valsalva maneuver should be used.
There is no effect of pressure on the ears and sinuses.
The effects of pressure are manifested equally to all people.

questions.question: Immediately after taking off, the pilot must pay attention to:
options: If the other pilots present at take-off were willing to fly so as not to do it alone.
Maintain the direction of the wing and stabilize the flight before making any necessary adjustments.
If there are other pilots flying close to take-off.
The correct direction and intensity of the wind.

questions.question: The Paragliding pilot can be held responsible for not having avoided the collision.
options: Except when you are preparing to land.
Unless you are complying with all flight rules.
Unless the offender is the other pilot (s).
Always.

questions.question: The air heats up by:
options: Atmospheric diffusion.
Conduction mechanisms.
Energy discharges from the terrestrial poles.
Action of the sun together with the Coriolis force.

questions.question: The altitude that the thermal will reach and its speed depends on:
options: The proximity of humidity.
The direction and speed of the wind at the trigger point.
The characteristics of the atmosphere at that time.
The average dew point temperature.

questions.question: More consistent thermals can be found in:
options: Dry and dark soils.
Water tanks and other water mirrors.
Dense forests;
Long and sloping lawns.

questions.question: On a flight day, in the case of a strong and very consistent thermal, the wind:
options: Break it down into a very turbulent air mass in that area.
Undo the gradient and prevent this thermal from rising.
Compress it against the floor and do not allow it to come loose.
Contour it, as you do any obstacle, creating areas of windward and leeward.

questions.question: A low pressure of thermal origin:
options: It is formed by heating that instability the upper layers of the atmosphere.
Its occurrence can be increased by the entry of hot air in the upper layers of the atmosphere.
It ends up dissipating when the precipitation cools the air below.
None of the above.

questions.question: Regarding the formation of clouds and fronts:
options: A cloud formed by convection originates from a mass of air that rises and reaches the temperature of its dew point.
After the passage of a hot front, the temperature drops sharply, the pressure rises and the wind direction stabilizes strong from the northwest.
Cumulus humilis are always formed with low pressure or in the passage of a hot front.
The formation of cirrus clouds is an indicator of good thermal activity.

questions.question: Wet adiabatic gradient is the temperature variation of a portion of moist air when it rises or falls and is:
options: Approximately 0.6 millibars per 100 meters.
Approximately 0.6ºC per 100 meters.
Approximately 0.98 millibars per 100 meters.
Approximately 0.98ºC per 100 meters.

questions.question: In a tefigram we can predict:
options: When the air temperature line and the dew point line are overlapping, clouds of meteorological origin at that altitude.
When the air temperature line and the dew point line overlap, clouds of thermal origin at that altitude.
The thermal gradient of the day, provided that the dew point temperature at ground level is less than or equal to 0ºC.
The thermal gradient of the day, provided that the dew point temperature at ground level is equal to or greater than 0ºC.

questions.question: Looking at a tefigram with the following we can quickly conclude that:
options: It is a bad day to fly.
It is a good day to fly, with ceilings above 200mb.
It is a good day to fly, with ceilings at 200mb.
It is a good day to fly with ceilings below 200mb.

questions.question: With the previous image, and even in a quick and simple way, we can consider that ...
options: ... between 700 mb and 400 mb the wind should be from the Southwest.
... in these conditions cumulus humilis will form.
... there are only clouds above 800mb.
... is not a good condition for cloud formation.

questions.question: In the middle of a flight day, we will find thermal ascenders in areas:
options: Valleys protected from the sun.
With high contrast.
Very dense forest.
Slight and humid.

questions.question: To take advantage of the ascendancy, the pilot must turn “more closed” when the thermal is:
options: Weak and wide.
Strong and wide.
Strong and narrow.
Rotating more closely has no relation to the strength or dimension of the thermal ascendant.

questions.question: To make the flight profitable, the pilot must leave the thermal when:
options: The thermal upward trend is getting weak and it is already possible to reach a better one.
The thermal rise is strong and the rate of climb is very high.
There are other pilots going up in another thermal ascendant to the side.
There are other pilots in the same thermal ascendant and are unable to climb.

questions.question: When inside the thermal ascendant, the pilot must try to:
options: Stay still in relation to the ground or just with the speed of the drift so as not to leave it.
Exit and systematically enter the ascendant to find its limits.
Seek, systematically, stronger nucleus.
Fly in a zig zag to identify the best rate of climb.

questions.question: With the intention of making your flight profitable, if near the cloud the pilot finds a more consistent ascendant nucleus, he must:
options: Leave it immediately in "ears" or spiral to avoid the risk of entering the cloud.
Brake to take advantage of it until you enter the cloud slightly and then continue.
Accelerate to monetize the rate of climb and the flight avoiding entry into the cloud.
Go up until you get close to the cloud and then go down with “ears” or a spiral.

questions.question: Regarding the study of the speeds of a given profile.
options: A lower alar load implies greater speed.
The alar load has no relation to the profile speed.
A higher alar load implies less speed.
Less alar load means less speed.

questions.question: When a pilot encounters a good line, he must:
options: Follow it with the accelerator at maximum so as not to lose it.
Follow it taking into account any deviation from the route you are taking.
Abandon it quickly if the conditions of the day are of light wind.
Abandon it because, certainly, sooner or later it will make you enter a cloud.

questions.question: A pilot who, when landing, suffers a trauma to his foot, whose position appears to be different from normal, should suspect a fracture. Thus, we should proceed as follows:
options: Take off his shoes and put his foot in the normal position for the pilot to have less pain.
Do not remove his shoes and try to immobilize his foot in the position it is in.
Remove his shoes and try to immobilize his foot in the position it is in.
None of the above.

questions.question: In case of hemorrhage (bleeding) caused by a stick stuck in a thigh:
options: Apply cardiac massage.
Not to act and wait for the arrival of adequate means of assistance;
Apply indirect manual compression to the nearest artery.
Apply direct manual compression to the bleeding site.

questions.question: After a very violent landing on rocks, the victim complains of abdominal pain, looks pale, with cold sweats and is thirsty. We suspect:
options: Internal bleeding in the abdomen and we should not give it water. Just moisten your lips.
Head trauma and we should not give it water. Just moisten your lips.
Acute appendicitis and we should not give it water. Just moisten your lips
Transverse abdominal bone fracture and we should not give it water. Just moisten your lips

questions.question: Generally speaking, for the profitability of the flight it is essential:
options: In an ascendant, fly faster.
In a descent fly faster.
With a back wind, fly faster.
With head-on winds, fly slower.

questions.question: A very sharp decrease in the angle of attack in half the profile can cause:
options: A full stall.
A front collapse.
An asymmetric stall.
Asymmetric parachuting.

questions.question: If, in order to control a great resistance of the wing to enter a certain mass of air, the pilot drops his hands, the wing can enter in:
options: Asymmetric stall.
Full stall.
Parachuting.
Front collapse.

questions.question: The trimming:
options: Establishes the inclination of the wing in relation to the horizon.
It is defined by the angle formed between the ends of the leading edge and the middle.
It is the quocient between the maximum and minimum chords.
It is defined by the radius of the curvature.

questions.question: ​​As the wing load decreases, the same wing goes into stall at a horizontal speed:
options: Higher.
Equal
Lower.
The increase in the alar load has no relation to the speed of stall.

questions.question: Due to strong turbulence, the left half of the wing advances strongly and violently. To correct the flight position, the pilot must:
options: Pull the two brakes symmetrically.
Raise the two brakes symmetrically.
Pull the left brake and lift the right one.
Pull the right brake and raise the left one.

questions.question: Following a significant asymmetric collapse, the pilot must:
options: Cause a full stall to recover the shape of the profile.
Be concerned with preventing the rotation of the wing.
Use the accelerator to power the header and recover around it.
Relieve the brakes to prevent a full stall.

questions.question: Following a large tie, the pilot must be technically qualified and properly prepared to:
options: Pull the hand strongly on the side of the tie and lift the other one.
Pull the hand on the opposite side of the tie and lift the other one.
Raise both hands to allow faster recovery.
Open the emergency parachute.

questions.question: The pitch movement takes place on the axis:
options: Longitudinal and must be locked with the asymmetric action on the brakes.
Transversal and must be stopped with the asymmetric action on the brakes.
Transversal and must be locked with the symmetrical action on the brakes.
Longitudinal and must be locked with the symmetrical action on the brakes.

questions.question: The General Assembly of the Portuguese Free Flight Federation is the organ...
options: ... executive of FPVL.
... technical where schools decide on instruction.
... administrative authority that manages the way in which licenses are issued.
... of maximum decision and in which all pilots, instructors and judges are represented.

questions.question: At FPVL, the Arbitration and Competitions Council is a body...
options: ... elected.
... of appointment of the Board.
... of appointment of the President.
... of appointment of the General Assembly.

questions.question: The FPVL Competition Rules is a document that can be changed:
options: At a Board meeting.
At conferences.
For the administrative services.
None of the above.

questions.question: The Pilot's License:
options: It can be issued from the age of 16 with authorization from the Education Supervisor.
It can only be issued after the age of 18 years.
Can only be renewed 3 times.
It does not oblige the association to take out civil liability insurance.

questions.question: Current legislation:
options: Prevents the practice of Free Flying in type G airspace.
Establishes restricted areas for the practice of sports flying where no other aircraft can fly.
It requires the pilot to have a personal accident and civil liability insurance.
None of the above.

questions.question: The renewal of pilot licenses that have not been valid for 5 or more calendar years requires:
options: In the 12 months prior to the renewal request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
In the 3 months prior to the renewal request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.

Demonstration of having passed a flight test administered by a flight examiner in each of the relevant classes or types of aircraft in less than 3 months and having passed a written theoretical exam in less than 6 months.

questions.question: The flight rules state that:
options: A Paraglider has priority over a Paramotor.
Engine aircraft have priority over the others.
A Paraglider has priority over a balloon.
None of the above.

questions.question: Free flight is allowed
options: Only in air spaces where direct and constant communication with air traffic management is possible.
Only in uncontrolled airspace.
Next to the clouds, only while you can see the GPS.
None of the above.

questions.question: Prohibited areas can be associated with the defense of a state, so they are zones where:
options: For identification reasons, it is only allowed to fly below 5,000 feet (about 1,500m).
It is allowed to fly but there are potential dangers for air navigation, so its use is at the discretion of the pilot/commander.
It is allowed to fly only when expressly authorized.
It is not allowed to fly under any circumstances.

questions.question: Landing by parachute can be handled without injury when:
options: Good contact with the ground is made in a sitting position with feet apart.
If you are well prepared, relaxed and with your chin resting on your chest.
If you are prepared, running as much as possible when touching the ground.
None of the above.

questions.question: For the parachute to work as effectively as possible it is necessary that:
options: Have the connections and extraction system in good working order.
The connecting carabiners are not quick-opening.
The tissue is thin enough for air to penetrate easily.
The cords have been very well lubricated at the time of bending.

questions.question: The opening and maintenance of the emergency parachute
options: It can be done by the pilot himself, as long as he knows the technique perfectly.
Due to the risk involved, schools should not teach pilots how to do it.
It should be done in a place exposed to the sun to dry any moisture that exists in the fabric.
None of the above.

questions.question: The more regular review of the emergency parachute makes it present more:
options: Duration of elasticity in the cords.
Compression of the tissue so that it fits better in the container.
Humidity.
Speed ​​of opening.

questions.question: If a pilot, taking off at about 1.000 meters altitude, has...
options: ... headaches can be a symptom of hypoxia.
... nausea and vomiting are not symptoms of hypoxia.
... disorientation and uncoordinated movements may be symptoms of hypoxia.
... nausea and vomiting may be symptoms of hypoxia.

questions.question: Effects of pressure on the ears and paranasal sinuses:
options: There is no effect of pressure on the ears and sinuses.
The effects of pressure are manifested in the same way for all people.
With increasing pressure (descending), the valsalva manoeuver should be used.
With the pressure decreasing (rising), the valsalva manoeuver should be used.

questions.question: In the face of signs of great anxiety and even fear,
options: It is not a concern for a pilot, they are natural things for those who fly.
The pilot may have to make adjustments to the flight plan or even cancel it.
It should not be given much importance as long as there is no danger of panic.
The pilot must be taken immediately to a hospital emergency.

questions.question: The following are recommended for the Free Flight activity:
options: Accept warnings from more experienced pilots.
Allowing yourself to be influenced to take off by other people.
Try to decide to fly or not, based on esoteric or religious reasons.
None of the above.

questions.question: Vertical air movements:
options: They originate from the different degree of humidity in the soils.
They are not always very smooth and stable.
They are essentially due to the effect of temperature when added to the Coriolis force.
Even with some agitation and turbulence, they are never an impediment to a Paragliding flight.

questions.question: The speed of a thermal and the altitude it can reach is related to:
options: The proximity to places with more humidity.
The temperature it encounters throughout the atmosphere at any given time.
The direction and intensity of the wind at the trigger point.
The dew point humidity.

questions.question: A low pressure of thermal origin is a normal situation in the center of the Iberian Peninsula:
options: It is produced in summer, in the interior of the Iberian Peninsula due to the sea breeze that cannot reach it.
It is formed by heating the Mesosphere which destabilizes the upper layers of the atmosphere.
Its occurrence can be blocked by the entry of cold air at altitude.
It ends up dissipating when precipitation cools the air below.

questions.question: In Portugal, after the passage of a cold front, the temperature drops sharply...
options: ... the pressure rises and the wind direction stabilizes strong from the south.
...the pressure rises and the wind direction stabilizes strong from the northwest.
...the pressure is low and the wind direction stabilizes strong from the south.
...the pressure is low and the wind direction stabilizes strong from the northwest.

questions.question: It is considered a super adiabatic gradient, if the temperature drop is:
options: Less than 0.98°C per 100 meters.
Equal to 0.98 millibars per 100 meters.
Greater than 0.98°C per 100 meters.
There is no super adiabatic gradient.

questions.question: Considers a flight location with take-off at an altitude of 600m and with an atmosphere with the characteristics described in the table. It's a day:
options: A good adiabatic gradient. Good for flying.
Clear skies and no thermals. Too stable.
Cloud formation from the ground (600m).
None of the above.

questions.question: With the predictions in the previous table, we can consider that this moment is good for...
options: ... Staying at home and/or doing another activity.
... take-off calmly as it will be a direct flight. Just to “kill the addiction”.
... be on take-off prepared to take off.
...be in the air and ready to fly away.

questions.question: In the middle of the flight day, thermal ascendants are searched for:
options: Valleys more protected from the sun.
More dense forest.
Places with water.
High contrast areas.

questions.question: To make better use of the ascent, the pilot should run less inclined when the thermal is:
options: Weak and wide.
Weak and narrow.
Strong and narrow.
Rotating more flat or inclined has no relation to the strength or dimension of the thermal rise.

questions.question: When inside the thermal ascendant, the pilot should try to:
options: Search, systematically, for the strongest nucleus.
Keep almost stationary in relation to the ground or only with the speed of the drift so as not to get out of it.
Systematically exit and enter the ascendant to try to find its limits.
Flying in “U” to be able to identify the best rate of climb.

questions.question: Regarding the study of the velocities of a given profile.
options: Greater wing load implies greater speed.
Lower wing load implies higher speed.
Lower wing load implies higher speed.
Wing load is not related to profile velocity.

questions.question: To make the flight profitable, if near the cloud the pilot finds a more consistent ascending nucleus, he must:
options: Abandon it immediately in “ears” or spiral to avoid the risk of entering the cloud.
Brake a little to take advantage of it until you enter the cloud slightly and then continue.
Accelerate to make the most of the climb rate and the flight avoiding entry into the cloud.
Go up until you reach the entrance to the cloud and then go down with “ears” or spiral.

questions.question: When a pilot encounters an ascending line, he must:
options: Follow it with the accelerator at the maximum so as not to lose it.
Follow it, taking into account any deviation from the route he is taking.
Abandon it quickly if the day's conditions are windy.
Abandon it because, of course, sooner or later it will enter the cloud.

questions.question: A pilot who upon landing suffers trauma to a foot, whose position appears to be different from normal, should be suspected of having a fracture. Therefore, we should proceed as follows:
options: Do not remove your shoes and place your foot in the normal position.
Do not remove shoes, do not correct the position of the foot and immobilize with whatever is available.
Remove your shoes and place your foot in the normal position.
Remove shoes, do not correct the position of the foot and immobilize with whatever is available.

questions.question: In case of venous bleeding:
options: Simultaneously apply direct manual compression to both carotid arteries in order to reduce circulating blood pressure.
Always apply indirect manual compression. For reasons of blood failure.
Always apply direct manual compression if there are no stuck foreign bodies.
Acting only in order to reassure the victim and wait for the arrival of adequate means of assistance, as giving assistance in the wrong way can be a major complication.

questions.question: After a very violent landing in the middle of rocks, the victim complains of abdominal pain, is pale, has cold sweats and is thirsty. We suspect:
options: Internal bleeding in the abdomen and we should not give it water. Just moisten the lips.
Head trauma and we should not give him water. Just moisten the lips.
Acute appendicitis and we should not give it water. just moisten the lips
Fracture of the transverse abdominal bone and we should not give it water. just moisten the lips

questions.question: As for speeds:
options: The minimum fall rate velocity must be used to exit the descendants.
Minimum descent rate speed should be used to exit the risers.
The best glide speed is used to cover the longest possible distance in glide.
The best glide speed is the most used in high performance flights (competition).

questions.question: Generally speaking, for the optimization of in-flight speed, it is essential:
options: In an ascendant fly slower.
In an ascendant fly faster.
On a descending fly slower.
With a head wind, fly slower.

questions.question: A very sharp increase in the angle of attack in half of the profile can cause:
options: A front collapse.
An asymmetrical collapse.
An asymmetrical parachute.
An asymmetric stall.

questions.question: Trimming:
options: It is defined by the angle formed between the extremes of the leading edge and its center.
It is the quotient between the maximum and minimum chord.
It is defined by the mean of the radius of curvature.
Establishes the inclination of the wing in relation to the horizon.

questions.question: ​​With a lower wing load, flight incidents:
options: They are faster and more violent but more controllable.
Are slower soft and smooth but more controllable.
They are slower and smoother but less controllable.
They are faster and more violent but less controllable.

questions.question: Due to strong turbulence the left half of the wing advances strongly and violently. To correct the flight position, the pilot must:
options: Pull both maneuverers symmetrically.
Raise both maneuverers symmetrically.
Pull the left maneuverer and raise the right one.
Pull the right maneuverer and raise the left one.

questions.question: Following a significant asymmetric closure, the pilot must:
options: Cause a deep stall to more quickly recover the shape of the profile.
Use the accelerator to give energy to the heading and recover better around.
Be concerned about preventing the wing from rotating.
Relieve maneuverers to prevent stall.

questions.question: Following a big tie, the pilot may have to:
options: Pull the handler on the side of the tie and lift the other.
Pull the handler on the opposite side of the tie and lift the other.
Pull the two maneuverers until causing a total loss to recover the shape of the profile.
Raise both hands to allow the profile to regain its shape.

questions.question: Flying close to full speed is very demanding and asks the pilot as much attention and anticipation as possible, because:
options: The maneuverers have less action on the wing.
The turns after collapses are very slow.
The pendulous reactions of the wing are accentuated in all axes
Decrease wing pendulous reactions in all axes.

questions.question: In Portugal, the sports regulator for Free Flying and Paramotor is:
options: The Ministry of Transport.
The National Civil Aviation Authority, IP
The Portuguese Youth and Sports Institute, IP.
The Portuguese Free Flight Federation (FPVL).

questions.question: The FPVL Regulation of Instruction is a technical document that:
options: Only FPVL schools with a valid operating license can change it.
Establishes the training structure for Free Flight and Paramotor pilots and instructors.
Regulates the associative activity of FPVL.
Regulates all FPVL's competitive and training activity.

questions.question: The requirements to obtain a Pilot's License are:
options: 16 years and have been considered fit in the medical-sports evaluation.
16 years, regardless of having been considered fit in the medical-sports evaluation.
18 years old and have been considered fit in a medical-sports assessment exam.
18 years old, regardless of having been considered fit in the medical-sports evaluation.

questions.question: The revalidation of a pilot license requires:
options: In the 12 months prior to the revalidation request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
In the 3 months prior to the revalidation request, at least 5 flights in each of the classes or types registered in the license.
Have passed a flight test administered by a flight examiner in each of the relevant classes or types of aircraft, less than 3 months ago.
Have passed a written theoretical exam less than 6 months ago.

questions.question: Free flying is allowed
options: Exclusively in controlled airspaces in direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
Exclusively in uncontrolled airspaces in direct and constant communication with the air traffic management.
Within clouds as long as you can see the GPS and there is direct and constant communication with air traffic management.
None of the above.

questions.question: There are 3 types of restricted areas that can be observed on aeronautical charts:
options: Direct (D), Safeguarded (R) and Prohibited (P).
Direct (D), Reserved (R) and Prohibited (P).
Dangerous (D), Restricted (R) and Prohibited (P).
Dangerous (D), Restricted (R) and Scheduled (P).

questions.question: Current Portuguese legislation:
options: Prevents the practice of Free Flying in type G airspace.
Establishes restricted areas for the practice of sports flying where no other aircraft can fly.
It requires the pilot to have insurance with coverage for personal accidents and civil liability.
None of the above.

questions.question: As for the equipment:
options: Cell is the portion of the wing comprised between two main internal profiles.
The leading edge is the back of the wing when it is in flight.
The stabilizer is the back of the wing when it is in flight.
The stabilizer is the front of the wing when it is in flight.

questions.question: Regarding the approval of equipment:
options: They guarantee tests of structural resistance, longevity and durability of the material.
Ensure structural and flight strength tests.
Ensure flight tests and performance calculations in laminar wind conditions.
None of the above.

questions.question: As for measuring instruments:
options: An altimeter works based on the variation in atmospheric temperature.
An anemometer measures wind speed.
A variometer works based on the variation in wind speed.
A well-tuned wind sleeve always points north.

questions.question: When reviewing the parachute, the ideal will be:
options: Clean the cords and fabric with cold water and leave it in the sun until all moisture is removed.
Iron each pleat well, whenever possible, with a cold iron.
Put magnesium powder on the cords to reduce moisture and frictional tension.
None of the above.

questions.question: Still regarding the equipment:
options: The extrados is the underside of the wing when it is in flight.
The trailing edge is the back of the wing when it is in flight.
The stabilizer is the front of the wing when it is in flight.
Elevators join chair carabiners to tissue.

questions.question: At a take-off at 1.000 meters of altitude:
options: Headaches and disorientation can not be a symptom of hypoxia.
Nausea and vomiting can be symptoms of hypoxia.
Uncoordinated movements can be symptoms of hypoxia.
Vomiting can be symptoms of hypoxia.

questions.question: Valsalva manoeuvre should be used
options: With increasing altitude/ decreasing atmospheric pressure.
With decreasing altitude/increasing atmospheric pressure.
Only used in underwater diving activities.
When flying, never. There is no known effect of varying altitude/atmospheric pressure on the ears and sinuses.

questions.question: When taking off, the pilot must pay attention to:
options: Always inflate as quickly as possible.
Running, trying to jump to compensate for consecutive lack of wing pressure.
To other pilots who may be flying in the take off area.
The successive starts and stops necessary to compensate for the wing speed.

questions.question: For safety, in the practice of Free Flying it is recommended:
options: Do not give importance to the psychological state; having flying panic is a natural thing for human beings.
Taking off because of the need to show it to other people when you are not sure if you want to do it.
Do not ignore warnings from more experienced pilots.
None of the above.

questions.question: The air moves because...
options: ... the atmosphere is constantly trying to equalize the pressure and humidity differences caused by the different warming of the regions.
... the earth is in constant motion (Rotation and translation).
... the atmosphere constantly tries to equalize the pressure and temperature differences caused by the different warming of the regions.
... there is the force of Coriolis.

questions.question: Pressure system
options: Pressure is lowest in the centre of the anticyclone.
Pressure is highest in the centre of the cyclone.
Pressure is lowest in the centre of the cyclone.
The pressure is equal at the centre of the cyclone and the anticyclone.

questions.question: Isobars very close together indicates meteorological wind:
options: Practically nil.
Moderate.
Strong.
The proximity or distance of the isobars has no relation to the wind speed.

questions.question: With regard to front surfaces:
options: A front is a line that separates two air masses with different characteristics, mainly in terms of pressure and humidity.
A front can be cold, hot or occluded.
A frontal system is always associated with a strong north wind.
When passing a hot front we always have a north wind, sun and blue sky.

questions.question: The occlusion of the frontal system:
options: It is a unique meteorological phenomenon and very unlikely to happen.
It occurs when the cold front reaches the hot front.
It occurs when the hot front slows down, even being able to park.
None of the above.

questions.question: Cumuloninbus are:
options: Convection clouds with a shiny top that can reach over 10.000m in altitude.
Thick grey and shapeless.
It has a greyish-white appearance in which the sky appears to be covered with sheep.
None of the above.

questions.question: In your classification regarding altitude, the following are considered low clouds:
options: Cumulonimbus, Nimbostrata and Strata.
Altostratos, altocumulos.
Cirrus, cirrostratus and cirrocumulus;
None of the above.

questions.question: "Ears" are used in paragliding and are defined as a manoeuvre:
options: Emergency that allows stabilizing the rise in thermal.
That decreases the surface of the wing and increases the vertical speed.
Which stabilizes the wing by increasing the relation between its surface and the weight.
Instability that should only be used by acrobatic pilots.

questions.question: The take-off
options: “Reverse” technique should be the preferred technique in light wind situations.
“Alpine” technique should be the preferred technique when there is light wind.
The race must be done with the trunk straight and the eyes directed towards the wing.
None of the above.

questions.question: Wingover is an acrobatic manoeuvre...
options: ... too radical. Not to be used.
... to be used only by competition riders.
... whose learning must be done progressively.
... used to climb faster.

questions.question: Regarding the study of the velocities of a given profile, a polar velocity is established in the relationship between:
options: The maximum speed and rate of climb.
Horizontal speed and rate of climb.
Horizontal and vertical speed.
None of the above.

questions.question: A stall:
options: It is a sign that the pilot was using the speed bar. He must withdraw.
It is the moment when the pilot must immediately lower both hands to recover the wing.
It is a sign that the wing has reached a speed below its minimum flight speed
It is the moment when the pilot must immediately open the parachute.

questions.question: If a victim is found to have a deformity in the arm resulting from a fracture, he must:
options: Immobilize the arm, as it is, prevent the state of shock or control it, if any, and arrange for the victim to be transported to a hospital emergency.
Immobilize the arm as it appears and give it an object for the hand to keep squeezing in order to maintain blood circulation. Take the victim to the nearest hospital.
Stretch the arm, putting the bone in its proper place and then immobilize and transport the victim to a hospital emergency
Squeeze the deformed area tightly with a bandage, immobilize the victim on a stretcher and take him to the hospital.

questions.question: A pilot who upon landing suffers trauma to a foot whose position is different from normal, a fracture should be suspected. Proceed as follows:
options: Remove the shoes and place the foot in the natural position for the pilot to have less pain.
Remove the shoes, and immobilize the foot in the position it is in.
Do not remove shoes and immobilize the foot in the position it is in.
None of the above.

questions.question: In case of bleeding:
options: Never apply indirect manual compression.
Always apply, simultaneously with any other action, direct manual compression on both carotid arteries in order to reduce the circulating blood pressure.
Apply direct manual compression if the site does not have any ingrown foreign bodies.
Act to reassure the victim and wait for the arrival of adequate means of assistance. Getting help in the wrong way can be a big complication.

questions.question: The principle of lift has as a reference, with regard to its most common explanation, the flow of air in the soffit relative to the extrados, being:
options: The highest speed on the lower surface and the lowest on the upper surface
The highest velocity in the upper surface and the lowest in the lower surface.
The same speed in the upper surface and in the lower surface.
None of the above.

questions.question: ​​ On a wing defined as having a speed of 40 km/h (hands fully up), moving at 50 km/h, we can consider that:
options: Moves with head wind in the order of 10 km/h.
It moves with a side wind of around 10 km/h.
If there is no wind from behind, it is because the pilot is using the speed bar.
If there is no wind from behind, it is because the pilot is using the breaks.

questions.question: The maximum angle of attack corresponds to:
options: The maximum glide.
The minimum drop rate.
The maximum speed.
The minimum speed.

questions.question: When making a turn that is too slow, the wing can easily get into:
options: Sustained stall.
Asymmetric stall.
Dynamic stall.
Parachuting.

questions.question: The definition of wing load translates to:
options: In the relationship between the weight of the wing and its surface.
The relation between the total weight in flight and the surface of the wing.
The relationship between the weight of the flight equipment and the surface of the wing.
None of the above.

questions.question: The Instruction and Degree Regulations of the FPVL is a technical document that:
options: It can be changed only by the schools with a valid working permission.
Establishes 5 levels of free flight pilot.
Regulates the instruction, titles and training of free flight pilots and instructors.
Regulates all the FPVL activity concerning competition and training.

questions.question: If a pilot as done scuba diving, he should wait before flying:
options: If he has done one single dive, 15 days.
If he has done one single dive, 25 days.
If he has done several dives or several days diving, 30 days.
None of the above.

questions.question: Regarding the study of velocities of a given profile, a velocity polar is established in the relation between:
options: The maximum velocity and the rate of ascent.
The horizontal velocity and the rate of ascent.
The vertical velocity and the rate of fall.
The vertical velocity and the horizontal velocity.

questions.question: The principle of support has as reference, regarding its more usual explanation, the flow of air in the upper surface relative to the lower surface, being:
options: The lowest velocity in the lower surface is higher in the upper surface.
Same velocity in the lower surface and the upper surface.
The lowest velocity in the upper surface is higher in the lower surface.
In this explanation, there is no relation between the velocity of the air in the upper surface and that of the lower surface.

questions.question: When in motion, a paraglider is subject to resistances:
options: Pressure and friction.
Pressure. Only when above 28Km / h.
Friction. Only when above 28Km / h.
None of the above.

questions.question: A paraglider may stall if the pilot:
options: Decrease its speed below the maximum speed of flight.
Decreases its speed below the minimum speed of flight.
It increases its speed above the maximum speed of flight.
It increases its speed above the minimum speed of flight.

questions.question: Regarding the paraglider and wing loading of a profile:
options: The best glide is not altered by the wing loading.
The best glide is obtained with a lower wing loading.
The best glide is obtained with a higher wing loading.
None of the above.
